document_title: Nephrotic syndrome: Causes, symptoms and treatment
subsection_content:
1. Criteria for diagnosing nephrotic syndrome
Phew.; Increased proteinuria of more than 3.5g in 24 hours; Reduced blood protein below 60g/liter, accompanied by decreased blood albumin below 30g/liter.; Blood cholesterol increased from 6.5mmol/liter or more; Appearance of birefringent fat granules and fat pillars in urine
Criteria 2 and 3 are mandatory in diagnosing nephrotic syndrome. The remaining standards may not be complete.
2. Clinical diagnosis
Simple nephrotic syndrome: When fully determining the diagnostic criteria for nephrotic syndrome, there are no symptoms of hypertension, hematuria or kidney failure.; Nephrotic syndrome is not simple: In addition to the diagnostic criteria for nephrotic syndrome, there is also the presence of hypertension, gross or microscopic hematuria, or accompanied by kidney failure.
3. Diagnosis of nephrotic syndrome according to cause
Causes of primary nephrotic syndrome include:
Minimal change glomerulopathy; Membranous glomerulonephritis: In some developing countries, membranous glomerulonephritis is a common cause of nephrotic syndrome in adults; Focal sclerosing glomerulonephritis; Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis; Mesangial proliferative glomerulonephritis; Extravascular proliferative glomerulonephritis
Secondary causes of nephrotic syndrome include drugs, toxins, autoimmune diseases, malignant diseases, genetic diseases, metabolic disorders, infections and parasites...
4. Diagnosis through histopathology
Minimal change glomerulopathy; Membranous glomerulonephritis; Focal sclerosing glomerulonephritis; Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis; Mesangial proliferative glomerulonephritis; Extravascular proliferative glomerulonephritis.
5. Complications
People with nephrotic syndrome may have complications such as:
Infection: Acute or chronic infection occurs, most commonly cellulitis and peritonitis.; Embolism (thrombosis): Includes acute or chronic renal vein occlusion, limb vein and artery occlusion, iliac arteriovenous and splenic vein occlusion or, more rarely, pulmonary embolism.; Acute kidney failure.; Electrolyte disorders; Malnutrition; Complications due to medication use: Usually due to long-term use of corticosteroid drugs, or due to use of other immunosuppressants or diuretics.; Chronic renal failure.
If treatment is delayed, nephrotic syndrome can cause chronic kidney failure
